contentlets.description: Topic 1: Application of computer simulation techniques to geotechnical engineering problems. The course will cover mathematical model, finite-difference method for steady-state seepage and consolidation analysis; finite element method for steady-state seepage flow, transient seepage flow, stress analysis, consolidation analysis, staged construction and excavations; modelling techniques; applications of commercial finite-element packages; convergence study and error estimation. Topic 2: an introduction to the fundamentals of critical state soil mechanics and soil plasticity.
contentlets.title: Advanced Topics in Geotechnical Engineering

contentlets.description: Topic 1: Application of computer simulation techniques to geotechnical engineering problems. The course will cover mathematical model, finite-difference method for steady-state seepage and consolidation analysis; finite element method for steady-state seepage flow, transient seepage flow, stress analysis, consolidation analysis, staged construction and excavations; modelling techniques; applications of commercial finite-element packages; convergence study and error estimation. Topic 2: an introduction to the fundamentals of critical state soil mechanics and soil plasticity.
contentlets.title: Advanced Topics in Geotechnical Engineering

contentlets.description: Prerequisites: CVEN2201, CVEN3201 or equivalentAssessment of the suitability and design of stabilisation techniques for difficult foundation soils including instrumentation and application observational techniques to geotechnical engineering. Topics covered will include: principles of the observational method, instrumentation, selected lectures on braced excavations, dewatering, grouting, underpinning, stone columns, vertical and horizontal drains, vacuum pumping, deep compaction, vibrofloatation, lime stabilisation, reinforced earth and soil nailing.
contentlets.title: Ground Improvement and Monitoring Techniques

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CVEN4300 - Structures Practicum","description":"

A practical course that involves both advanced analysis and design of an engineered structure to solve a given problem. The course deals with behaviour of fundamental aspects of structural design, including advanced modelling. Students will work in groups to solve a specific problem; they will design and build their structure and then will then test it to destruction in the Heavy Structures and Materials Laboratories. Problems will be selected from concrete, steel, timber or other structural materials. The course is designed to enhance student capabilities in researching of design concepts, in further developing their problem solving skills and in determining design solutions to a client's problem.

At midway, teams will present a progress report on their preliminary structural designs, project completions project planning to the client.

Oral presentation: Group 5%

Report chapter drafts to be submitted prior interview (individually) - group members interviewed and feedback and mark provided (15% - individual)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"019d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"099d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"499d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"859d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c19d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"309d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96198d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"50","description":"

Groups to provide a report to the client on the finalisation of their design and predicted performance. A detailed model for their design solution is to be presented. The final design report is to be provided at, or prior to, testing.

Group is to write an Introduction to the Report and a Outcomes Chapter. Group 10%

Group members will be interviewed, individuality, on the outcomes, on contribution and on their tasks - evaluations are individual. A mark will be derived as a combination of interview and their written contribution (Chapter). Individual 40%

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"019d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"099d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"499d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"859d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c19d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"789d8537dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961991","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Final Presentation and Reflection","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Groups to present their testing observations and alignment with, or evaluated reasons for variance from, their details design and design predictions.

Group Assessment: 10%

Each group member will submit a report reflecting on their own contributions, outcomes and learning experience. Individual assessment: 10%

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Undergraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Diploma, Advanced Diploma, Associate Degree or a Bachelor Degree (pass or honours).","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Undergraduate","value":"ugrd"},"code":"CVEN4301","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CVEN4301 - Advanced Concrete Structures","description":"

A course on the advanced analysis and design of concrete structures for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering. The course deals with the design and behaviour of the following fundamental aspects for reinforced and prestressed concrete member design: one-way and two-way concrete slabs (including the direct design, equivalent frame and simplified strip methods); retaining walls, strip, pad and pile footings; and determinant prestressed concrete members. Additional topics  may be drawn from the following: design for torsion, detailing; ductility; preliminary sizing of members and frames; design with high strength and fibre reinforced concretes.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"d591ed3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619ed","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 3","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"10","description":"

The main objective of this individual assignment is to provide opportunities for students to reinforce their knowledge about principles of prestressed/post-tensioned concrete (PC) design.

The main objective of this individual assignment is it to encourage students to engage with the subject content as soon as possible and develop an understanding about principles of simplified and advanced methods in design of RC structures.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1d91ed3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"9d91ed3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a9619e6","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8591ed3bdb7d1c50eb6b147a3a961982","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

The main objective of this group assessment is to provide opportunities for students to reinforce their knowledge and understanding of advanced reinforced concrete design with emphasis on deflection control of slabs under service load and practical design of slabs under ultimate conditions according to AS3600-2018 provisions.

contentlets.description: A course on the advanced analysis and design of concrete structures for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering. The course deals with the design and behaviour of the following fundamental aspects for reinforced and prestressed concrete member design: one-way and two-way concrete slabs (including the direct design, equivalent frame and simplified strip methods); retaining walls, strip, pad and pile footings; and determinant prestressed concrete members. Additional topics  may be drawn from the following: design for torsion, detailing; ductility; preliminary sizing of members and frames; design with high strength and fibre reinforced concretes.
contentlets.title: Advanced Concrete Structures

Reactive powder concrete. Fibre Reinforced Plastics (FRP): advanced polymer composites for structures; polymer matrix materials; fibres used properties of polymers; properties of fibres; structural applications; durability of FRP.

contentlets.description: A course on the advanced analysis and design of structural elements for students looking towards a career in Structural Engineering. The course covers: design of compression members, effective lengths of columns, design of plate girders (local buckling in shear, combined shear and bending, intermediate transverse stiffeners, web crippling â?? buckling and yield limit state) design by buckling analysis, design of portal frames, behaviour and design of beam-columns, connection design, plastic design (beams, simple frames), introduction to composite steel-concrete structures, elastic and rigid plastic analysis of composite beams, composite columns, composite connections, introduction to structural fire engineering.
contentlets.title: Steel and Composite Structures

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CVEN4309","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CVEN4309 - Sustainable Timber Engineering","description":"

Structural and Construction Engineers may be responsible for the design and construction of timber structures; from timber frame housing to high rise engineered timber structures. This course provides an introduction to the design of timber structures using a range of timber products and the relevant Australian and European Standards. It further outlines the considerations to design for Durability, Fire, Manufacture and Assembly that play an important role in timber engineering.

of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CVEN4310 - Deformation Monitoring Surveys","description":"

This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for deformation monitoring to civil engineering students with an interest in structures or geotechnical. Topics include: Principles and concepts of deformation monitoring by surveying techniques. Project surveying methodology. Control survey network adjustments and simulations. Atmospheric effects on optical and radar measurements. Terrestrial Laser scanning. Underground mine and tunnel surveys. Open cut mines, wall monitoring. Subsidence monitoring above underground mines. Monitoring high rise buildings. Tiltmeters and GPS for high frequency bridge monitoring. Motorised total station instruments and automatic target recognition for dam and wall monitoring. High precision (sub-mm) survey techniques. 3D theodolite intersection measuring systems. Laser trackers. Dam deformation surveys. Close Range Photogrammetry, for monitoring scale models, building facades and heritage structures.

contentlets.description: This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for deformation monitoring to civil engineering students with an interest in structures or geotechnical. Topics include: Principles and concepts of deformation monitoring by surveying techniques. Project surveying methodology. Control survey network adjustments and simulations. Atmospheric effects on optical and radar measurements. Terrestrial Laser scanning. Underground mine and tunnel surveys. Open cut mines, wall monitoring. Subsidence monitoring above underground mines. Monitoring high rise buildings. Tiltmeters and GPS for high frequency bridge monitoring. Motorised total station instruments and automatic target recognition for dam and wall monitoring. High precision (sub-mm) survey techniques. 3D theodolite intersection measuring systems. Laser trackers. Dam deformation surveys. Close Range Photogrammetry, for monitoring scale models, building facades and heritage structures.

Monitoring high rise buildings. Tiltmeters and GPS for high frequency bridge monitoring. Motorised total station instruments and automatic target recognition for dam and wall monitoring. High precision (sub-mm) survey techniques. 3D theodolite intersection measuring systems. Laser trackers. Dam deformation surveys. Close Range Photogrammetry, for monitoring scale models, building facades and heritage structures.

contentlets.description: This course introduces the concepts, principles and techniques used for deformation monitoring to civil engineering students with an interest in structures or geotechnical. Topics include: Principles and concepts of deformation monitoring by surveying techniques. Project surveying methodology. Control survey network adjustments and simulations. Atmospheric effects on optical and radar measurements. Terrestrial Laser scanning. Underground mine and tunnel surveys. Open cut mines, wall monitoring. Subsidence monitoring above underground mines. Monitoring high rise buildings. Tiltmeters and GPS for high frequency bridge monitoring. Motorised total station instruments and automatic target recognition for dam and wall monitoring. High precision (sub-mm) survey techniques. 3D theodolite intersection measuring systems. Laser trackers. Dam deformation surveys. Close Range Photogrammetry, for monitoring scale models, building facades and heritage structures.
contentlets.title: Deformation Monitoring Surveys

contentlets.description: Analytical techniques for urban land use/transport planning practice. Planning methodology: traffic generation, trip distribution, modal-choice, traffic assignment, evaluation. Land use forecasting: calibration and verification of behavioural models, application of mathematical programming models, case studies, public transport problems.
contentlets.title: Urban Transport Planning

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CVEN4402","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CVEN4402 - Transport Systems - Part 1: Network Analysis","description":"

This subject covers strategic planning aspects related to transport systems, including transport network-based analysis, modelling and optimisation techniques. Network representation of transport systems and traffic route choice modelling including user equilibrium and system optimal are the two main broad topics that will be discussed in this subject. Knowledge about different types of transport network solutions and when and where to apply them are important for transport professionals. The subject material focuses on network theory in some depth, and a reasonable mathematical competency, as well as the ability to perform computational work, will be required to follow this subject. Computer literacy will be helpful but is not essential.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"983e5fb1dbb65810eb6b147a3a96191e","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 2 will focus on Network Equilibrium Models. The questions will be based on the material covered in lectures and workshop. The assignments are intended to build on the skills developed in workshop, and help prepare the students for the final exam. Assignments will be assessed on the technical merit and consistency of the methodology followed, with consideration given to the clarity of presentation.

contentlets.description: Historical introduction to transport systems and development of various transport modes, road (vehicles, pedestrians, cycles), conveyor, rail, sea and air. Analysis of the operational characteristics of vehicles in the transport modes of road, rail and air. Analysis of congestion-related issues using queuing theory. Development of optimum criteria for the distribution of cargo and passenger traffic. Terminals and mode transfer facilities. Development of system operational models. Energy considerations. New systems.
contentlets.title: Transport Systems - Part 2: Queuing Theory

CVEN4404: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering aims to provide undergraduate students the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute as a practicing Traffic Engineer. The course will cover the broad topics of traffic flow theory and modelling, traffic control device design and implementation and traffic management practices. Students will have the opportunity to analyse real traffic data, develop traffic management plans and design traffic control devices using industry prevalent modelling software such as "SIDRA Intersection" and "Aimsun", developing necessary practical skills as a Traffic Engineer.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5e7d8137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96190f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Understanding Traffic Flow Theory","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment focuses on students "Understanding  Traffic Flow Theory" that has been presented during the first 3 weeks of the semester. The assignment will involve solving a series of problems, extending from the problems discussed during the lectures. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

This assignment will be submitted on Moodle and online individual feedback will be provided to each student

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"717d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8e7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"617d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-Term Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Mid-Term exam will cover all the material until and including Week 5 of the course, and is intended to assess students’ knowledge of the expected learning outcomes, prepare students for the final exam, and discourage last minute cramming. The exam will be assessed on technical accuracy.

Students will be provided individual feedback concerning performance and exam solutions will be provided for review prior to the final exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"717d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8e7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c27d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a97d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Practical Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment allows students to display their understanding of how to conduct a traffic study and propose traffic management schemes for realistic scenarios. The assignment will involve investigating a case study and using the knowledge gained within the lectures to develop solutions for the specific case. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

This assignment will be submitted on Moodle and online individual feedback will be provided to each student

contentlets.description: CVEN4404: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering aims to provide undergraduate students the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute as a practicing Traffic Engineer. The course will cover the broad topics of traffic flow theory and modelling, traffic control device design and implementation and traffic management practices. Students will have the opportunity to analyse real traffic data, develop traffic management plans and design traffic control devices using industry prevalent modelling software such as "SIDRA Intersection" and "Aimsun", developing necessary practical skills as a Traffic Engineer.
contentlets.title: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CVEN4404","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CVEN4404 - Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering","description":"

CVEN4404: Fundamentals of Traffic Engineering aims to provide undergraduate students the knowledge and skills necessary to contribute as a practicing Traffic Engineer. The course will cover the broad topics of traffic flow theory and modelling, traffic control device design and implementation and traffic management practices. Students will have the opportunity to analyse real traffic data, develop traffic management plans and design traffic control devices using industry prevalent modelling software such as "SIDRA Intersection" and "Aimsun", developing necessary practical skills as a Traffic Engineer.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"5e7d8137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96190f","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1: Understanding Traffic Flow Theory","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment focuses on students "Understanding  Traffic Flow Theory" that has been presented during the first 3 weeks of the semester. The assignment will involve solving a series of problems, extending from the problems discussed during the lectures. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

This assignment will be submitted on Moodle and online individual feedback will be provided to each student

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"717d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8e7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"617d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a3","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-Term Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The Mid-Term exam will cover all the material until and including Week 5 of the course, and is intended to assess students’ knowledge of the expected learning outcomes, prepare students for the final exam, and discourage last minute cramming. The exam will be assessed on technical accuracy.

Students will be provided individual feedback concerning performance and exam solutions will be provided for review prior to the final exam.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"717d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d3","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"8e7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c27d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619f7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"ca7d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619d8","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"a97d4137dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2: Practical Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

This assignment allows students to display their understanding of how to conduct a traffic study and propose traffic management schemes for realistic scenarios. The assignment will involve investigating a case study and using the knowledge gained within the lectures to develop solutions for the specific case. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

This assignment will be submitted on Moodle and online individual feedback will be provided to each student

Human factors is the scientific discipline concerned with the understanding of interactions between humans and other elements of a system. The profession applies theory, principles, data and methods to the design process to optimise human well-being and overall system performance. This course, which also encompasses the field of engineering psychology, will equip students with the fundamental knowledge and skills necessary for human-centred design across many civil engineering disciplines, with a focus on the road and traffic management system to optimise its performance and make it safe, efficient and satisfying to use. Students will also gain an appreciation of the critical human considerations that are critical in the successful design, operation and evaluation of intelligent and automated transport systems (including connected and automated vehicles), now and into the future.

The profession applies theory, principles, data and methods to the design process to optimise human well-being and overall system performance. This course, which also encompasses the field of engineering psychology, will equip students with the fundamental knowledge and skills necessary for human-centred design across many civil engineering disciplines, with a focus on the road and traffic management system to optimise its performance and make it safe, efficient and satisfying to use. Students will also gain an appreciation of the critical human considerations that are critical in the successful design, operation and evaluation of intelligent and automated transport systems (including connected and automated vehicles), now and into the future.

contentlets.description: An introduction to lumped and distributed catchment runoff models; an introduction on the rationale used for model verification and validation, model development and parameter estimation; Bayesian methods for estimating model parameters; reservoir and channel routing; reservoir operation and design; wetland design and conceptual processes; introduction to stochastic generation of hydrologic time series in the context  of water resources management.
contentlets.title: Catchment Modelling and Water Resources Management

contentlets.description: Theory of periodic waves in coastal waters. Wave growth, refraction, diffraction, shoaling and breaking processes. Measurement, analysis and prediction of waves. Coastal and beach processes including tides, storms, currents and elevated water levels, morphology, sediment transport mechanisms, beach erosion and nourishment, prediction and modelling of shoreline change. Wave forces on coastal and ocean structures with application to practical engineering design of harbours, breakwaters, seawalls, piles, decks, marinas, pipelines and outfalls.
contentlets.title: Coastal Engineering

contentlets.description: Review of groundwater occurrence in Australia.  Physical properties of groundwater and groundwater occurrence. Principles of groundwater flow. Storage and transmissivity - impacts of groundwater abstraction. Groundwater in the hydrological cycle: flow nets; surface water groundwater interconnectivity. Groundwater modelling. Unsaturated zone flow and calculation of infiltration. Groundwater recharge mechanisms and water balance calculations. Drilling methods for groundwater abstraction; geophysical logging; well design and completion for water production bores. Solutions to the radial flow equation; pumping test interpretation; a program of field work and data analysis will be undertaken at the UNSW Farm in Wellington.
contentlets.title: Groundwater Resource Investigation

contentlets.description: Detailed examination of unit processes used in water and wastewater treatment including chemical selection, dosing and mixing, coagulation, flocculation, clarification, filtration and disinfection technology in water treatment and sedimentation and aerobic and anaerobic biological processes in wastewater treatment. Integrated design of water and wastewater treatment facilities with attention given to both conventional and advanced treatment technologies such as membrane and advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) and the application of online measurements and process control for treatment system monitoring.
contentlets.title: Advanced Water and Wastewater Treatment

contentlets.description: Professional elective that in any offering may include various combinations of the following topics:- river morphology, river engineering and stream remediation; models for channel and river routing; model theory, selection, calibration, validation and reliability; models may include Muskingham, kinematic wave, non-inertial and diffusion and dynamic wave; sediment and pollutant transport methods and models including plug-flow and advection-dispersion in both coupled and uncoupled applications; hydraulic control structures; estuarine classification and density structure; tides, water level response, mixing processes and flushing of rivers and estuarties; hydrodynamic stratification and algal dynamics; random walk and box models; biochemical processes in rivers and estuaries.
contentlets.title: River Engineering

The course enables engineers to analyse and design sustainable infrastructure to support the needs of urban and regional economies and populations. It builds on and applies the concepts learned in introductory tools, water, transport and engineering operation courses in Stages 1 to 3 of the program. It provides an urban or regional context to the planning and design of infrastructure in the areas of water and waste management, transport services, energy supply and distribution; and introduces planning methods to enable system thinking to design from macro to asset specific scale so that sustainable outcomes are enabled for urban and regional communities.

contentlets.description: Waste audits and characterisation of hazardous wastes in regions and industries; control of generation and transport of hazardous waste, manifest systems; waste minimisation; on-site treatment methods; integrated off-site treatment facilities; management of residues from treatment facilities; introduction to planning of regional hazardous waste management systems. Characteristics of individual waste types (dioxins, PCBs, pesticides, heavy metal, etc.) and waste management in individual industries (steel, pulp and paper, petro-chemical, food processing, etc.).

contentlets.keywords: civil and environmental engineering,water quality,water treatment,wastewater treatment
contentlets.description: Fundamental aspects of the chemistry and biology of aquatic environments are reviewed and extended enabling analysis and interpretation of processes occurring in surface and ground waters as well as water and wastewater treatment systems. Tools are developed enabling solution of realistic water quality problems including introduction to use of chemical speciation computer codes and other water quality modeling packages.
contentlets.title: Advanced Water Quality Principles

contentlets.keywords: civil and environmental engineering,water quality,water treatment,wastewater treatment
contentlets.description: Fundamental aspects of the chemistry and biology of aquatic environments are reviewed and extended enabling analysis and interpretation of processes occurring in surface and ground waters as well as water and wastewater treatment systems. Tools are developed enabling solution of realistic water quality problems including introduction to use of chemical speciation computer codes and other water quality modeling packages.

Sustainability Assessment and Risk Analysis","assoc_campus":null,"assoc_url":"/postgraduate/courses/2021/CVEN9892","assoc_class":"Course","assoc_award_titles":null,"assoc_state":"show","assoc_award_single":"","assoc_code":"CVEN9892","assoc_class_translated_subjects":"Course","assoc_faculty":"Faculty of Engineering","assoc_class_translated":"Program","assoc_duration_hb_display":"","assoc_current_version":{},"links":[]}],"search_title":"CVEN4705 - Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management","description":"

An introduction to sustainable engineering principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by public and private sector sustainability managers to implement sustainable engineering principles in organisations, regions, projects and processes. Sustainability assessment techniques are introduced that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER). 

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c118357ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a9619bc","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1 (Group)","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

In the first assignment students need to calculate the full Carbon Footprint (CF) of their own household, benchmark and evaluate the results, recalculate the CF for hypothetically changed consumption pattern and elaborate on ways to minimise the CF through their own actions and those from various stakeholders. Students will prepare one group report to be submitted to Turnitin, where feedback will be provided

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"c518b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"c518b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"cd18b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a961970","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"cd18b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a961971","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d518b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a961973","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"dd18b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a961972","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b118b57ddb6b9810eb6b147a3a9619e9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The quizzes will test the students' ability to synthesise specific parts of the course, demonstrate understanding of main principles and implement them in given situations. May include calculations.

In the second assignment, students need to prepare an individual presentation on a given topic. Depending on the number of students in the class this will be either an oral presentation or a poster presentation. Feedback will be given directly after the presentation.

contentlets.keywords: civil and environmental engineering,environmental sustainability,ecologically sustainable development,environmental impact statement,environmental management system,environmental reporting,industrial ecology,life cycle assessment (lca),environmental footprint,material flow analysis (mfa),input-output analysis,ecological footprint,carbon footprint,water footprint,sustainable engineering
contentlets.description: An introduction to sustainable engineering principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by public and private sector sustainability managers to implement sustainable engineering principles in organisations, regions, projects and processes. Sustainability assessment techniques are introduced that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).
contentlets.title: Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management

Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management","description":"

An introduction to sustainable engineering principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by public and private sector sustainability managers to implement sustainable engineering principles in organisations, regions, projects and processes. Sustainability assessment techniques are introduced that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).

In the first assignment students need to calculate the full Carbon Footprint (CF) of their own household, benchmark and evaluate the results, recalculate the CF for hypothetically changed consumption pattern and elaborate on ways to minimise the CF through their own actions and those from various stakeholders. Students will prepare one group report to be submitted to Turnitin, where feedback will be provided

contentlets.keywords: civil and environmental engineering,environmental sustainability,ecologically sustainable development,environmental impact statement,environmental management system,environmental reporting,industrial ecology,life cycle assessment (lca),environmental footprint,material flow analysis (mfa),input-output analysis,ecological footprint,carbon footprint,water footprint
contentlets.description: An introduction to sustainable engineering principles and the social, economic and political context in which they have arisen, and in which they are implemented. It introduces methods, techniques and tools used by public and private sector sustainability managers to implement sustainable engineering principles in organisations, regions, projects and processes. Sustainability assessment techniques are introduced that can be applied at a product level (Life Cycle Assessment), at a corporate and regional level (Materials Flow Analysis) and at a regional and national level (Environmental Footprint and Input-Output Analysis). The course will introduce principles of Industrial Ecology (IE) and the preparation of Environmental Impact Statements (EIS), Environmental Management Systems (EMS) and Environmental Reports (ER).
contentlets.title: Environmental Sustainability - Methods, Tools, Management

Research Thesis A","description":"

The thesis provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis. Thesis projects are complex, open-ended problems that allow room for your creativity, and the acquisition, analysis and interpretation of results. There are multiple possible solutions or conclusions at the outset and sufficient complexity to require a degree of project planning. The thesis requires you to formulate problems in scientific or engineering terms, manage an technical project and find solutions by applying scientific and engineering methods. You will also develop their ability to work in a research and development environment. You must identify a supervisor and project prior to enrolling in this course. This is the first course of the 3 course thesis structure.

The course involves undertaking and completing a series of design tasks in either civil or environmental engineering depending on whether students are undertaking the civil or environmental stream. The design tasks are chosen in one of the following areas: structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, project management, transport, environmental and/or water engineering. Each design task in the series may be independent of each other, or may be a sequence of related sub-tasks as part of a larger goal.


Assessment of each task requires the construction of working system to solve a specified problem.

contentlets.description:
The course involves undertaking and completing a series of design tasks in either civil or environmental engineering depending on whether students are undertaking the civil or environmental stream. The design tasks are chosen in one of the following areas: structural engineering, geotechnical engineering, project management, transport, environmental and/or water engineering. Each design task in the series may be independent of each other, or may be a sequence of related sub-tasks as part of a larger goal.

Assessment of each task requires the construction of working system to solve a specified problem.
contentlets.title: Civil Engineering Design Practice

Masters Practice Project A","description":"

This course is a core research enquiry course for those enrolled in either the Civil or Environmental Engineering streams in the 8621 accredited Masters program. This is the first part of the coursework project, with CVEN9051 Masters Practice Project B, following this course in a later term. This course enhances the student’s skills for undertaking scholarly enquiry by attempting to achieve a specific topic objective within a defined period of time. A significant component of the course relates to the review of literature, which promotes independent and reflective learning as well as increases students’ capacity to develop information literacy. The project work is expected to reinforce the student’s ability and confidence in the written communication of technical information.The intention with this course is to bring into focus the skills needed to investigate real life projects. The Masters Practice Project A topic is presented to the student as it would be in industry and each student is required to prepare an individual submission by way of an Engineering Report that contains all of the elements required within the Assessment Overview. Topics are related to industry projects selected from contemporary practice. The work involves industry based investigations and design applications.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"b7d5a88bdb14201055a93324f3961988","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project Development","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Project development and design calculations. These are specific to the project and involve the student completing independent work with assigned data sets. The individual tasks are completed using relevant design procedure(s), Australian Standards, current design manuals, and students are required to complete a literature search to identify other relevant literature and background information specific to their assigned tasks. Limited to three (3) separate submission tasks, these several parts each become an appendix of the Final Report above (2. Practice Project Report A).

[Comment: Whilst marking is progressive across a Term, a student can assemble the elements in Practice Project Report A into a single Engineering Report document they can present to others (at say, an interview).

Practice Project Report A enables a student to demonstrate their capacity in being able to undertake work practice in a 'new' discipline area within their profession in which that they have not had any previous training, and present their work (which is heavily biased in containing design calculations and explanation of their rigour) by way of a comprehensive, professional report. Armed with this document a student going to a job interview, will readily be able to demonstrate how they can work professionally in a workplace team environment, have the confidence to complete independent work assigned to them and present their outputs in a professional manner.] 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"33d5a88bdb14201055a93324f39619f9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33d5a88bdb14201055a93324f39619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"33d5a88bdb14201055a93324f39619fb","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"3bd5a88bdb14201055a93324f39619f9","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40e5e88bdb14201055a93324f3961904","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Critique","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Students are required to make a presentation (in student pairs) to their assigned Workshop. In this assessment task students are to required to present an outline of their Thesis A Project Development as if they were presenting their work to a senior reviewer (Demonstrator) in an organisation they are working within. As students have developed different solutions each will be required to discuss their progress by outlining the strengths and the weakness areas in what they have developed, with students required to make a coherent team presentation integrating their different parts.

The student critique will be presented in their scheduled Workshop and assessed at that time by their Demonstrator. Generally a common mark is assigned to each student pair for their presentation and discussion, unless the Demonstrator argues the reason why a mark variation (not exceeding 10% difference between the marks)  should be awarded to the recipients and the Course Coordinator agrees with the Demonstrator's reason(s).

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"33d5a88bdb14201055a93324f39619fa","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"33d5a88bdb14201055a93324f39619fb","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"40e5e88bdb14201055a93324f3961916","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practice Project Report A","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"30","description":"

The Practice Project Report A document is to be presented as an Engineering Report and will be marked accordingly: Executive Summary: 10% Presentation/ content: 10% Writing/ reference quality: 10%. The detail provided in the this 'Final Report' is to a nominated maximum page limit, which is to ensure that the Final Report is concise; the Report integrates the appendices from the detail listed below (3. Project Development).

","erg":[],"campus":{"name":""}},"additional_information":"","study_level_tooltip":"Postgraduate: A level of study that leads to the award of a Graduate Certificate, Graduate Diploma, Masters Degree or Doctorate.","campus":"Sydney","study_level_single":{"label":"Postgraduate","value":"pgrd"},"code":"CVEN9051","attributes":[],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CVEN9051 - Masters Practice Project B","description":"

This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after the completion of CVEN9050 Masters Practice Project A, usually in the proceeding Term. The project involves formulating the designs for and solution to open-ended civil and/or environmental problems. The problems will be drawn from industry and will be multi-disciplinary involving application of material learnt throughout the postgraduate program and will require creative thought. The course will include the preparation of relevant professional documents. Part B involves the satisfactory preparation and submission of an individual report addressing the well-justified project plan.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"2696553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961920","name":"Independent research - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Abstract and Final Report","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"55","description":"

Abstract and Final Report Assessment Criteria

A student's individual Masters Practice Project B submission is presented as an Engineering Report, restricted to 30 pages, and will contain an additional Abstract.

The marking of the submission is as follows: 

(i) Abstract: 5%

(ii) Executive Summary: 10%

(iii) Presentation/ content including writing/ reference quality: 10%

(iv) Quality of work and discussion of results/ findings/ design aspects: 25%

(v) Conclusion and added value: 5%

[Comment: Students should regularly attend the weekly scheduled lecture and have to attend and contribute in their scheduled  weekly Workshop.Whilst marking is progressive across a Term, a student can assemble the elements in Practice Project Report B into a single Engineering Report document they can present to others (at say, an interview); which demonstrates their capacity in being able to prepare a comprehensive, professional report. Different to Practice Project Report A, this Project Report B allows a student to clearly demonstrate an aspect of engineering that they find within their interest area for future professional employment.]

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1e96153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2696553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6296553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6e96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aa96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"1e96153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Topic Nomination and Thesis Plan","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"5","description":"

Topic Nomination and Thesis Plan Assessment Criteria

Each student is required to select a topic of interest within a nominated contemporary project. Each student has to discuss topic options with their Demonstrator and finalise their unique Thesis topic. The submission requirement is a 2-page Assignment which contains a 1-page descriptive outline of their chosen topic and the student's a project timeline for the Term, meeting all submission deadlines.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"1e96153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"2696553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6296553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6e96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aa96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"5696153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619e9","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Literature Review submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

A student is required to undertake a 'limited' Literature Review of their selected topic. Restricted to 5 pages, the 'limited' literature review forms part of the the Masters Practice Project B submission.The focus of the Literature Review is for the student to identify the current practice of their selected topic to enable them to complete the design of their nominated topic to contemporary accepted standards. 

The Literature Review is a critical part of any practical project design process. It is expected that the most significant areas of literature relevant to the proposed Masters Practice Project B submission are reviewed, analysed and documented in a formal manner to show the historical development, major contributions, current status as well as the future trends in the project topic areas.

The Demonstrator will grade the submission.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6296553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"6a96153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619f5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aa96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8a96153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Site Inspection Report or Workshop Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Site Inspection Report or Workshop Presentation Assessment Criteria

Each student is required to complete, EITHER:

(i) a Site Visit Inspection Report for a defined project locality. A student is required to conduct their site inspection from public viewing areas and therefore are not required to enter a construction site. The Site Inspection Report is restricted to 5 pages and will be included as an Appendix to the final submission,

OR,

(ii) a Workshop Presentation for projects that are in the planning stage and have not yet commenced construction. The individual presentation is given in a scheduled Workshop to their peers and Demonstrator. The presentation is to be not longer than 10 minutes and is restricted to not more than 12 power-point slides. In delivering a presentation the student has to outline to their peers their Masters Practice Project B topic, progress against their timeline, the reason why they selected their topic, what has been learned and what remains to be done finalising their Masters Practice Project B. The Workshop Presentation is to be included as an Appendix to the final submission. The Workshop Presentation is a learning engagement opportunity for all students to gain a more comprehensive understanding about an upcoming project.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"6296553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961910","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"6e96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961904","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"aa96553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a961907","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"e696553fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a96190a","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c296153fdbf91c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CVEN9051.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.description: Analytical techniques for urban land use/transport planning practice. Planning methodology: traffic generation, trip distribution, modal-choice, traffic assignment, evaluation. Land use forecasting: calibration and verification of behavioural models, application of mathematical programming models, case studies, public transport problems.
contentlets.title: Urban Transport Planning Practice

Modelling transportation demand and safety; a broad range of econometric modelling techniques and its application to transportation systems will be considered; specific emphasis will be placed on estimation of these models and their use for forecasting and interpretation of results;  transportation data, analysis and modelling including considerations of data sources, errors, time series analysis, stochastic models and extensions to simulation and optimisation in transportation systems.

contentlets.description: Definition of basic traffic elements, zero flow travel time, capacity, impedance flow relationship. Transport networks. The determination of shortest path, maximum flow, in networks. The topological description of networks. Location theory applications in relation to transport networks. System parameters, performance. Application of network analysis to existing road, rail and air transport systems.

Energy consideration, new systems.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"4b4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619c4","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 1","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

The assignment tests a student’s ability to understand and interpret the available real-world traffic data, which will also be used in the group project assessment later in the course. The questions will be marked based on technical and methodological accuracy.

This is an individual assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3a4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"764d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"834d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2a4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961973","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"1-pager on Guest Lecture","assessment_type":{"label":"Attendance","value":"attendance"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"5","description":"

This submission will be based on the Week 7 Guest Lecture. Students have to present a summary of the lecture.

This is an individual assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3a4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"cf4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"624d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The assignment tests a student’s understanding towards simulation techniques used in queueing theory. The knowledge tested through this assignment will later be used in the group project assessment later in the course. The questions will be marked based on technical and methodological accuracy.

This i an individual assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"724d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"834d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fa4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"30","description":"

The project involves developing queueing models to analyse vehicle flow at a traffic intersection using the available real-world dataset used in assignment 1. Students have to form teams comprising a maximum of 4, on Moodle, prior to commencing project work. The aim of the project is to give students an experience of the practice followed by transport consultants in proposing solutions to real-world problems in transport. Students will also get experience working in a team environment and collaborating with team members during this project activity. The report will be marked based on technical and methodological accuracy.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3a4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"764d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"834d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"cf4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e24d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Moodle Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

An online quiz will be administered via Moodle. The Moodle quiz will be based on the material covered in the first 3 weeks lectures and workshops. The Moodle quiz will assess students understanding on the basics tenets of queueing theory which will be applicable to the rest of the assessments in the course. The questions will be marked based on technical accuracy.

The Moodle quiz will be made accessible at the beginning of Week 4 lecture. The Moodle quiz will be an open-book assessment. Students must submit their responses while the quiz is still active. Failure to complete/submit a quiz within the accessible time period will result in a mark of zero. It is strongly recommended that students attend Week 4 lecture to attempt the online Moodle quiz in the class.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"724d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"be4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961999","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fa4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"ee4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96196e","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/CVEN9415.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}
contentlets.description: Historical introduction to transport systems and development of various transport modes, road (vehicles, pedestrians, cycles), conveyor, rail, sea and air. Analysis of the operational characteristics of vehicles in the transport modes of road, rail and air. Analysis of congestion-related issues using queuing theory. Development of optimum criteria for the distribution of cargo and passenger traffic. Terminals and mode transfer facilities. Development of system operational models. Energy consideration, new systems.
contentlets.title: Transport Systems Part 2

The assignment tests a student’s ability to understand and interpret the available real-world traffic data, which will also be used in the group project assessment later in the course. The questions will be marked based on technical and methodological accuracy.

This is an individual assessment.

This submission will be based on the Week 7 Guest Lecture. Students have to present a summary of the lecture.

This is an individual assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3a4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"cf4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"624d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961978","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Assignment 2","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"30","description":"

The assignment tests a student’s understanding towards simulation techniques used in queueing theory. The knowledge tested through this assignment will later be used in the group project assessment later in the course. The questions will be marked based on technical and methodological accuracy.

This i an individual assessment.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"724d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961997","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"834d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"fa4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199c","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"aa4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96197c","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Group Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"5","weighting":"30","description":"

The project involves developing queueing models to analyse vehicle flow at a traffic intersection using the available real-world dataset used in assignment 1. Students have to form teams comprising a maximum of 4, on Moodle, prior to commencing project work. The aim of the project is to give students an experience of the practice followed by transport consultants in proposing solutions to real-world problems in transport. Students will also get experience working in a team environment and collaborating with team members during this project activity. The report will be marked based on technical and methodological accuracy.

 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"3a4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a96199f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"764d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a2","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"834d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"cf4d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a9619a7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"e24d89f3dbb91c50eb6b147a3a961981","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Moodle Quiz","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"15","description":"

An online quiz will be administered via Moodle. The Moodle quiz will be based on the material covered in the first 3 weeks lectures and workshops. The Moodle quiz will assess students understanding on the basics tenets of queueing theory which will be applicable to the rest of the assessments in the course. The questions will be marked based on technical accuracy.

The Moodle quiz will be made accessible at the beginning of Week 4 lecture. The Moodle quiz will be an open-book assessment. Students must submit their responses while the quiz is still active. Failure to complete/submit a quiz within the accessible time period will result in a mark of zero. It is strongly recommended that students attend Week 4 lecture to attempt the online Moodle quiz in the class.

contentlets.description: Historical introduction to transport systems and development of various transport modes, road (vehicles, pedestrians, cycles), conveyor, rail, sea and air. Analysis of the operational characteristics of vehicles in the transport modes of road, rail and air. Analysis of congestion-related issues using queuing theory. Development of optimum criteria for the distribution of cargo and passenger traffic. Terminals and mode transfer facilities. Development of system operational models. Energy consideration, new systems.
contentlets.title: Transport Systems Part 2

This postgraduate course covers engineering methods applied to transport logistical systems. In this course, the material provided will cover the basics of graph theory, algorithmic complexity and mathematical programming, which are critical tools to solve complex decision-making problems arising in the field of transportation. These advanced methods will be then used to create engineering solutions to manage existing logistical systems as well as answer questions on transport infrastructure needs. Throughout the course, these techniques will be illustrated on challenging transport and logistics problems such as network flows, facility location, vehicle routing, transit systems as well as rail and air logistics. After completing this course, students will have been exposed to efficient methods and their application to solve transport and logistics decision-making problems. The course will use real data for a course project as well as invite leading practitioners to present their expertise on selected topics. This course will help address the gap of transport logistics engineering in the Masters for Transportation Engineering Curriculum.

The final written examination will be in the conventional closed book format covering all topics introduced throughout the course. The final examination will consists of a series of problems and focus on theoretical and methodological concepts presented within the lectures as well as within previous assessments. The final examination will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

The Assignment will be released in Week 6 and will be due in Week 9. contentlets.keywords: civil and environmental engineering,transport logistics engineering,transportation
contentlets.description: This postgraduate course covers engineering methods applied to transport logistical systems. In this course, the material provided will cover the basics of graph theory, algorithmic complexity and mathematical programming, which are critical tools to solve complex decision-making problems arising in the field of transportation. These advanced methods will be then used to create engineering solutions to manage existing logistical systems as well as answer questions on transport infrastructure needs. Throughout the course, these techniques will be illustrated on challenging transport and logistics problems such as network flows, facility location, vehicle routing, transit systems as well as rail and air logistics. After completing this course, students will have been exposed to efficient methods and their application to solve transport and logistics decision-making problems. The course will use real data for a course project as well as invite leading practitioners to present their expertise on selected topics. This course will help address the gap of transport logistics engineering in the Masters for Transportation Engineering Curriculum.
contentlets.title: Transport Logistics Engineering

Traffic engineering professionals are tasked with the responsibility of ensuring the safe and efficient movement of people and goods through the provision and maintenance of transportation systems. The effectiveness of the transport system defines the economic development and quality of life for the entire community.  This course offers students an advanced understanding of the field of traffic management and control, with a focus on traffic flow theory and characteristics of both motorised and non-motorised traffic. The course covers topics including fundamentals of traffic flow theory and analysis, queuing theory, shockwave theory and analysis, microscopic simulation, design and operations of unsignalised and signalised intersections, and network traffic flow.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c6d3b40adb7b5850eb6b147a3a961973","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Understanding Theory","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 1 will be released 6/3/2019 (week 3) and will be due on 20/3/2019 (week 5). This assignment focuses on students understanding of the theory of traffic flow that has been presented during the first 4 weeks of the semester. The assignment will involve solving a series of problems, extending from the problems discussed during the lectures. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

Final exam

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"4ed3b40adb7b5850eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"92d3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92d3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"92d3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"2ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619ff","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Simulation Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"20","description":"

Assignment 2 will be released on 15/4/2019 (week 9) and will be due on 1/5/2019 (week 11). This assignment allows students to display their understanding of how to develop a microscopic simulation and propose traffic management schemes for realistic scenarios. The assignment will involve investigating a case study and using the knowledge gained within the lectures to develop solutions for the specific case. The assignment will assess the expected learning outcomes and will be assessed based on technical accuracy, clarity in reporting and presentation.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"4ed3b40adb7b5850eb6b147a3a961974","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"92d3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"92d3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"92d3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"9ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619be","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"9ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619bf","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"9ad3380adb7b5850eb6b147a3a9619c0","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"36d3780adb7b5850eb6b147a3a961908","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Mid-term","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

An open-book mid-session exam will be administered on 25/3/2019 during the first 90 minutes of the week 6 lecture. The exam will cover all the material until and including week 5 of the course and is intended to assess studentsâ€™ knowledge of the expected learning outcomes, prepare students for the final exam, and discourage last minute cramming. The exam will be assessed on technical accuracy.

Masters Project A","description":"

The project provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis. Master projects are complex, open-ended problems that allow room for your creativity, and the acquisition, analysis and interpretation of results. There are multiple possible solutions or conclusions at the outset and sufficient complexity to require a degree of project planning. The project requires you to formulate problems in scientific or engineering terms, manage an technical project and find solutions by applying scientific and engineering methods. You will also develop the ability to work in a research and development environment. You must identify a supervisor and project prior to enrolling in this course. This is the first course of the 3 course project structure.

contentlets.description: The project provides an opportunity for you to bring together engineering principles learned over your previous years of study and apply these principles to innovatively solve problems such as the development of a specific design, process and/or the investigation of a hypothesis. Master projects are complex, open-ended problems that allow room for your creativity, and the acquisition, analysis and interpretation of results. There are multiple possible solutions or conclusions at the outset and sufficient complexity to require a degree of project planning. The project requires you to formulate problems in scientific or engineering terms, manage an technical project and find solutions by applying scientific and engineering methods. You will also develop the ability to work in a research and development environment. You must identify a supervisor and project prior to enrolling in this course. This is the second course of the 3 course project structure.

contentlets.description: Geotechnical features of geological environments including igneous, volcanic, metamorphic, sedimentary and carbonate. Geological structure and environmental effects including; stress, valley bulging, tectonic setting, glaciation, weathering and alteration; and Holocene geology. Geomorphology, the surface expression of the underlying geology and geological processes. Total geology and geotechnical engineering models. Planning of site investigations and the parameters required, drilling, trenching and in-situ permeability of soil and rock. In-situ testing of soil, including SPT, CPT, piezocone, vane shear. Laboratory testing of soil including triaxial, direct shear and ring shear. Field instrumentation for pore pressure and displacement. Geotechnical mapping. Geological, structural, geotechnical, geomorphological, air photo, specialised vector maps and landslides.
contentlets.title: Geotechnical Models and Site Investigation

Principles of foundation types and design. Shallow foundations - general bearing capacity equations for vertical and inclined loads, settlement calculation, foundations in sand, rock and reactive clays. Earth pressures, retaining structures. Piles - advanced analysis of pile capacity, group analysis, lateral loading, dynamic integrity testing and analysis settlement analysis. Cast in-situ piles, sheet piles, diaphragm walls, anchored and strutted walls, - analysis and construction methods. Analysis of soil nailing and anchors in excavations. Design of footings for dynamic loading.
