Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"CVEN9932 - Masters Project B","description":"

This course is the second of two parts and is undertaken after CVEN9931 Masters Project A. Successful completion of Parts A and B are required to obtain the equivalent of 12 UOC in CVEN9930 Masters Project. Admission to CVEN9931 and CVEN9932 is subject to approval of the Specialisation Authority - progression to CVEN9932 is dependent upon satisfactory completion of CVEN9931 in preceding term. The Masters Project may describe directed research work on an approved subject and will be completed under the guidance and supervision of a member of the academic staff. The research may involve a directed laboratory or field investigation, analytical or numerical modelling, a detailed design, literature review or such other individual research project approved by the Head of School. Part B involves independently completing the research project and writing a thesis fully describing the problem, the nature of the work undertaken, the aims and objectives, the research methodology, the research outcomes, results and conclusions.


","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"62f07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961982","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Research Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"10","description":"

Each student will present their thesis project on the day of the Research Thesis Seminar Presentations. Date, time and place to be confirmed. Ten minutes will be devoted to each presentation and 3 minutes will be spent on questions from the audience, plus 2 minutes for change-over (total 15 minutes per student). The seminar presentations will be assessed by the academics in the room.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"12f07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1af03d73db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"96f07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"aaf07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a96194c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"daf03d73db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0af03d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961998","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis Submission","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"85","description":"

Students submit their thesis to the School office for assessment as 2 hard copies and a PDF document. The thesis will be assessed by their supervisor and a second assessor. The thesis submission is assessed against learning outcomes and expected standards of performance. The assessment criteria and performance descriptors (rubrics) are provided. The criteria which are assessed are: - Criterion 1: Lit review/background and putting the results in context (10%) - Criterion 2: Execution of the research project, quality of analysis, discussion of results, (60%) - Criterion 3: Conclusions, and value added (10%) - Criterion 4: Document presentation (20%)

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"12f07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961947","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"1af03d73db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e7","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"6ef07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961949","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"96f07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961941","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"d2f07d73db315c50eb6b147a3a961944","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"daf03d73db315c50eb6b147a3a9619e4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"42f03d73db315c50eb6b147a3a96199d","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Thesis Abstract","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"5","description":"

Students are required to submit an abstract of their thesis project (300 words or less). The purpose of this Abstract submission is to compile the summaries of all the Projects to be presented in the Research Thesis Seminar Presentation for distribution to all Seminar attendees (staff and students in the School of Civil and Environmental Engineering). The abstract is marked by the course coordinator. The text of the abstract should include all of the following: â€¢ Purpose of study â€¢ Methodology, including study design and analyses â€¢ Summary of results â€¢ Conclusions
